item.content:encoded:
Updates

  • A number of improvements to the lazy image loader in the Modal view

  • The order of releases on your dashboard is now by the release date, with unpublished releases coming first

Bugfixes

  • Only attempts to auto-open the Modal if the setting is enabled, and it can reliably remember state (so it doesn't always open on every visit for some users)

  • Fixed CORS issue with embeddables in some situations

  • Fixed issue with featured image size in Modal headers

  • Fixed an issue where opening a specific release with JavaScript (e.g. rnw('show', '123xzy')) wouldn't load images in the content

item.content:encoded:
It's one thing to announce that you've made a release, but how do you know it's not falling on deaf ears?

To combat that, today V1 of analytics has been released. In this initial release you're able to see an overall breakdown of how many views your releases are getting over time, broken down into three buckets: web, modal, and email.

Change the date range from the picker in the top right to zoom in or out to whatever time period you'd like to check on. 

As you publish new releases, you'll also see those annotated on the charts as you can see below with the purple vertical line to the right end of the chart below.

A report that shows how many new subscribers you're getting over time is also available. This shows how many new subscribers you gained on any given day. Again, new releases are shown as an annotation, so you can see if a certain release was responsible for a bump in subscribers.


NB Views started being collected from April 21, as such, that is the furthest back you can view analytics.

Analytics are available on the Standard and Pro plans, and can be found at https://app.releasenotes.io/analytics

item.content:encoded:
It's one thing to have a site that lists your updates, but that relies your customers visiting that site.

Now, you can embed your release notes right within your site or web app with the Release Notes Modal, and Release Notes Banners

ReleaseNotes Modal

This is a great way to showcase your latest releases right from within your site, so your users are always made aware of the latest changes. Simply install our code snippet on your site, and tie it to any link or icon on your site to get a badge that shows the user how many unseen releases there have been since they last checked them out.

You even have the ability to automatically show the modal if there's new unseen releases for that customer.

Check out the example below, and learn more here.

ReleaseNotes Banners

The modal is great for when you have logged in users, but what about your marketing site, what's the best way to let visitors know what your most recent update was, to show them that you're actively improving your product?

That's where the ReleaseNotes Banners come in, but adding a simple bit of html like this: 

<rn-banner></rn-banner> 

You can embed a banner on your site that will always be up to date with your most recent update, just set and forget, it couldn't be easier.

Check out the examples below (and on the releasenotes.io home page), and learn more here.

New Features

  • ReleaseNotes Banner

  • ReleaseNotes Modal

item.content:encoded:
Recently, an update was made to the main pricing of ReleaseNotes.io, which came inline with a range of new features, one of which being Private Releases to make it easy to share updates with your team. The intended audience for this was for remote teams, and private projects. This feature was reserved for the Pro plan.

In response to the COVID-19 outbreak, and the mass movement of companies responsibly electing to have all non-essential staff work from home, the Private Releases feature will now be made available on the Standard plan until the worst of COVID-19 is behind us all.

Hopefully this will help to keep your now remote team up to date with the progress of your product, privately.

Stay safe. ‚ù§Ô∏è

item.content:encoded:
Pricing for ReleaseNotes has remained the same since it was launched 2 years ago. In that time a lot has been learned about what people need, and how they're using ReleaseNotes. 

As a result, pricing has had a refresh to make it simpler, and provide levels that suit each type of team.

Two Plan Types

For most teams, the standard plan will be enough to get you up and going. It has allowance for subscribers and announcing your releases to them over email, selecting a theme other than the standard theme, unlimited team members, and more.

But if you're looking for more control, like custom domain, custom theme, API access, and private notes, then the Pro plan is what you'll need.

The full details of each plan are below.

Auto-scaling Subscribers

Rather than creating a new plan for each different band of subscriber counts, as well as blocking subscriptions when you reached your plans arbitrary cap, subscribers are now a simple addition to your base plan at the flat rate of just $10 per 1,000 subscribers (regardless of which plan you select), automatically added to your monthly invoice.

If you don't want to pay for subscribers, simply don't add any, easy :)

Introducing the Free Plan

Sometimes all you need is a place to hang your hat, no bells and whistles. Or perhaps you're just getting started with your product and just need to get the ball rolling on sharing your progress. 

That's exactly what the free plan aims to cover. With the free plan, you can display 6 months of your release history (older releases will remain hidden), and use the standard theme at zero cost.

New Features

  • New plan types

  • Auto-scaling subscriber pricing

  • Free plan
